Change is indeed inevitable, and I only worked to pay tribute to a moment and a people that I hold in high regard. Already established. There's been cd-rom editions of the Britannica since the 1990s; many of them contain a great deal more than simply the encyclopaedia (I have a 2004 3-cd edition that's also got Merriam-Webster's big dictionary and so on, great stuff; bought it for ten pounds through Amazon as a 'spot purchase'). The cd/dvd editions are sure to stay in production and get updated. The article just doesn't mention them

I think it's better to continue the encyclopedia in form of ebooks instead of completely stop the effort. Online encyclopedia is hardly a trustworthy reference, especially in the scientific environment. But it's also very understandable that more people today hardly need a trustworthy reference for casual needs. It also requires much more effort to keep the encyclopedia updated in this open and fast pace information era. That's why it's also getting harder to sold it in the form of hard books. Then, why not take the intermediate solutions? Keep make it but make it as ebooks. This way, the authors could keep updating the informations as fast as the online website (though still got published annually), the publisher could cut the production cost pretty much significantly, and the buyer could get a trustworthy reference with richer content (as ebooks support multimedia and interactive content) with lower price. Everybody happpy! :)

Having worked with urban project kids in an experimental high school, what made the school work was the prime role of the the arts - drama, music, painting. These core learning/expression activities (not extra-curriculars) allowed for passion, passion being something real to adolescents. Students regularly developed their own play and movie productions based on their own lives but also influenced by the classic plays they acted and helped direct. O yes, "academic" skills were also taught, and learned well, but as a secondary consideration to the arts.

What also worked was democratic governance and original classes proposed by teachers or students and run - if enough students wanted them.

The consent - often the passion - of the learners was always in operation.

Of course none of this would be possible today, with the obsession with "standardized" testing and the busywork required to prepare for these utterly boring tests.

Having sold Grolier's New Book of Knowledge juvenile set way back when Britannica was at their peak, I see this as the end of an era.

I also see it as self inflicted: the distribution of educational books primarily sold door to door by a transient sales force with schlocky one-call closes at the kitchen table never, ever made sense to me. They would have sold far more books and made plenty of money had they reduced the price and eliminated the clip on tie crowd.

I wonder if and when other sets, such as the World Book I grew up with, will follow.

I agree that online sources have more agility than print, but I fear that future generations will never know the pleasure that comes with turning the page of a really good book.
